stories.text:
I “nearly”invented an entirely new class of software, but went out of business before getting there.

Many years ago I came up with a concept that dominates the world of software today, and I did it before anyone else. My idea lacked only one critical feature.

My idea was so very close to being an idea that within a few years others would complete, leading to untold riches.

And for me nothing but failure.

Every day I think about how very very close I was to gigantic success.

How do I deal with this constant looking back?

Surely others feel the same way, nearly being highly successful, nearly finding the winning formula, being only an inch away from winning.

How do people handle this? How do you handle being inches from immense success, and instead being loser?
stories.title: Ask HN: How do you deal with “nearly successful”?
I cut my cloud bill by 95% using Traefik, Tailscale, and K3s
Feeling stressed? It's “a bit weird”, but tapping helps – and it's easy to learn
The FIP-FS “Microsoft” Scan Engine Failed. Can’t Convert “2201010001” to Long

stories.text:
Reading HN usually makes me wonder the background of its members, so here are a few questions I would like to know:

- Where are you from?

- How old are you?

- In what field do you work? If it is related to CS, please specify the industry (SWE, AI, graphics etc)

- What did you study?

- What interests/hobbies do you have?
stories.title: Ask HN: General Questions for HN Readers
